# Introduction

This report analyzes 2022 World Development Indicators data [@worldbank_wdi].
We focus on GDP per capita, life expectancy, and unemployment rate.

# Analysis

```{python}
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
df = pd.read_csv("wdi.csv")

cols = ["gdp_per_capita", "life_expectancy", "unemployment_rate"]

# Summary statistics
print(df[cols].describe())

# Plot 1: GDP Distribution
plt.figure()
plt.hist(df["gdp_per_capita"].dropna(), bins=30)
plt.title("Distribution of GDP per Capita (2022)")
plt.xlabel("GDP per Capita (US$)")
plt.ylabel("Number of Countries")
plt.show()

# Plot 2: Income and Life Expectancy
tmp = df[["gdp_per_capita", "life_expectancy"]].dropna()

plt.figure()
plt.scatter(np.log10(tmp["gdp_per_capita"]), tmp["life_expectancy"])
plt.title("Life Expectancy vs Log10 GDP per Capita (2022)")
plt.xlabel("Log10 GDP per Capita")
plt.ylabel("Life Expectancy (Years)")
plt.show()

# Plot 3: Top 10 Unemployment Rates
u = df[["country", "unemployment_rate"]].dropna().sort_values("unemployment_rate", ascending=False)
top_u = u.head(10)

plt.figure()
plt.bar(top_u["country"], top_u["unemployment_rate"])
plt.title("Top 10 Unemployment Rates (2022)")
plt.xlabel("Country")
plt.ylabel("Unemployment Rate (%)")
plt.xticks(rotation=60, ha="right")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

Conclusion

GDP per capita is highly skewed.

Income positively relates to life expectancy.

Unemployment varies widely across countries.
